What is Open Research?

Open research involves approaches to conducting and disseminating research in a way that makes it open, transparent, and accessible to everyone in society.
Open research incorporates a range of actions taken at all stages of the research cycle.
Open research helps to make all aspects of the research process more transparent and helps make knowledge generated by research publicly available.

Many people have heard the term open science. Open science can be defined as the movement to make scientific research, data, and dissemination accessible to all levels of an inquiring society. It can also be viewed as research simply done properly.
In this course, we use the term open research instead of open science. This reflects the inclusion of all disciplines in which research is conducted.
Some aspects and practices of open research can differ depending on the area you are studying. This introductory course will help you identify what aspects are useful overall and for your specific context.
There are five schools of thought about open research.

The infrastructure school relates to making research platforms, tools, and services openly available.
The pragmatic school relates to enhancing efficiency of knowledge creation and research.
The public school relates to making research accessible to the public.
The democratic school relates to making knowledge available to everyone.
And the measurement school relates to developing and using alternative approaches to measuring impact.

Methodological issues and questionable research practices
‚è≠Ô∏è Skip ahead to watch the video presentation
üìä or see the slides
Did you know the internet was originally designed for research purposes? Researchers wanted a fast, easy, and low-cost way of sharing data with each other. So the internet was born. Now the internet dominates almost all aspects of our daily lives. Yet it has deviated from its original purpose.
Open research is the movement to bring modern research back in line with its original digital intent.
The open access movement began in the early 1990s with the aim to make research products available to everyone including the general public.
Improving transparency and reproducibility relates to making research processes and outputs more open so other researchers could examine and reproduce them.
The open science movement was aimed at correcting bad science and restoring public trust in scientific research.
Open research. It became evident that more open research practices could apply across disciplines, not just in science. This would ensure reproducibility, transparency, and collaboration across disciplines.
Open research methods are still evolving within the sciences, and some disciplines are just beginning to develop open research methods that suit their subjects.
Part of the move towards open research was driven by problems that were becoming apparent in the scientific literature.
Open research partly emerged in response to methodological crisis whereby it was not possible to replicate or reproduce many scientific studies and findings.
This reproducibility crisis or replicability crisis has been most commonly reported in psychology and some areas of health and medicine.
For example, in one survey of over 1,500 researchers, more than 70% had tried and failed to reproduce another researcher‚Äôs findings, and more than half had failed to reproduce their own findings.
Open research also aims to address questionable research practices.

title: 1.2 History of Open Research
text:
What are questionable research practices?


They are practices and techniques that do not follow best research practice.
They can be used to get a desired research result or report research findings in a more favorable manner.
They undermine trust and confidence in research findings.
They introduce bias to research processes and findings.


Questionable research practices can take place at any stage of the research process.
Selective reporting involves cherry-picking and publishing only findings that are novel, exciting, or statistically significant.
Underspecified methods involves not sharing methods with other researchers in enough detail so that they can attempt to replicate it. Data dredging, exploiting the data to achieve novel, exciting or statistically significant results, HARKing, hypothesizing after results are known, reporting unexpected findings as though they were expected from the start.

Why do researchers engage in QRPs?

Bad science is not always conducted by bad researchers. So why does it happen? The perception that more research outputs is better creates pressure to publish. This can negatively impact how people do research. They may cut corners to get more research published. Profit motives or ideological commitments might make researchers engage in poor practices.
Poor research practices might also just reflect how researchers were taught in the first place.
Researchers can also just make mistakes.

As a student, it can be easy to engage in QRPs. If I think exciting or significant results will lead to a better grade, I might engage in questionable research practices. Time constraints and coursework pressures can also lead to cutting corners.
It is important to guard against questionable research practices in all your research activities. This ensures the research you conduct is robust and trustworthy.

Increased and ongoing awareness of issues around reproducibility and QRPs has led to improved open research practices. Open research practices can improve the validity and integrity of research. Though poor methods exist, open research aims to improve them. It is these practices and the underlying principles of open research that we will introduce you to in this course.

Did you know making and having open research is so important that it is in the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights? According to this document, everyone has the right to freely participate in the cultural life of the community, to enjoy the arts, and to share in scientific advancement and its benefits. Everyone has the right to the protection of the moral and material interests resulting from any scientific, literary, or artistic production where they are the author.

Less poor research practices and greater research accountability

How does open research discourage poor research practices?

Open research encourages researchers to publicly disclose the details of their methods. These can then be reviewed, assessed, and validated by other researchers. This may discourage use of questionable research practices.
How does open research help us identify methodological issues in research?

The Case of Covid-19
The Covid-19 pandemic provides a stark example of the ways poor research design can lead to poor outcomes. It also shows how open research can help us identify invalid results before they become the basis for bad clinical practice.

For example, during the pandemic, a trial was conducted to assess the use of hydroxychloricquin, an antimmalarial drug to treat severe CO 19. The study reported reduced mortality in patients who received the drug. As a result, hydroxychloricquin began to be touted as a ‚Äòcure‚Äô.

But when a preprint of the study was published and other researchers began to review it, they identified a major flaw in the study design. This flaw likely affected the results. So the paper was withdrawn and hydroxychloricquin is not an approved treatment for Covid-19.

Encouragement of broader society participation in research

How does open research encourage societal participation in research?

Including members of the public when conducting research is important for a number of reasons.

It enhances the relevance and impact of your research.
It helps to ensure fair access to knowledge and reduce inequalities.
Inclusion of the public in conducting research is called citizen research.

How does open research encourage societal participation in research?


Open research findings and outputs can be freely accessed by the public. This means there are no fees or need to use an institutional login.
Open research makes it easier for research to reach the public. This means people outside academia can engage with research outputs.
It is not just research papers that can be made freely available. Textbooks can be made openly available too. For example, via Open Textbook Library.


Sharing of knowledge in open research also involves non-traditional roots including social media, public talks, blogs, visuals, and infographics. Using diverse approaches to share knowledge and research increases the likelihood that people can and will engage with it.

Why is open research important for me?

Why is open research important for me?

We come across research findings every day in the news, on television, and online. Having a better understanding of open research allows you to better engage with the research you read and hear about.

Understanding good practices and spotting bad practices means you can judge how reliable and trustworthy a piece of research is.
If you go on to apply for a master‚Äôs or PhD funding, research funders increasingly require open research practices for grant applications.
If you decide to publish your project, many journals now encourage open practices, including registering studies in advance and sharing data. Some journals also award badges for open research practices.

Sharing your research also means it‚Äôs more likely to be read and or engaged with, meaning you have a greater chance of making an impact with your research.
By sharing drafts of research early, you can get feedback from researchers all over the world to help improve your research. This can be scary, but it can also be worth it!

Sharing data and research materials online also means they can be cited by other researchers because they are assigned digital object identifiers, DOIs.
How often your work is cited is an academic metric that is often used to decide on job opportunities and promotions.
If you use open research approaches, future prospective employers will be able to see your research outputs and processes. This can enhance your job applications, including outside research in academia.

Open research practices
Now that you have a sense of what open research is about in terms of the principles of open research, we will provide an introduction to using open research practices.
Principles include transparency, reproducibility, accountability, collaboration, and societal engagement.
Practices include research integrity, pre-registration, reproducible practices, research data management, open reporting, and knowledge dissemination.
Open research practices. Open research practices or methods are relevant at all stages of the research process, including research planning, data collection, data analysis, writing up and publishing findings, and disseminating and sharing your research.
Each of the open research practices introduced here are discussed in the next sections.
Guiding principles of research integrity
Research integrity involves making honest and responsible decisions at all stages of the research cycle. It prioritizes reliability, ensuring quality of research at all stages of the research process, honesty, developing, conducting, sharing, and engaging with research in fair, transparent ways.
Respect for research participants, colleagues, society, culture, and the environment. And accountability for the research, its management, and for wider impacts.
Why is research integrity important?
1. It reduces the likelihood of research misconduct.
2. It ensures the validity of research results.
3. It facilitates trust between researchers. 4. It promotes trust in data and research expertise.

What does open research involve? Open research practices. Now that you have a sense of what open research is about in terms of the principles of open research, we will provide an introduction to using open research practices.
Principles include transparency, reproducibility, accountability, collaboration, and societal engagement.
Practices include research integrity, pre-registration, reproducible practices, research data management, open reporting, and knowledge dissemination.
Open research practices. Open research practices or methods are relevant at all stages of the research process, including research planning, data collection, data analysis, writing up and publishing findings, and disseminating and sharing your research.
Each of the open research practices introduced here are discussed in the next sections.
Research integrity
Guiding principles of research integrity.
Research integrity involves making honest and responsible decisions at all stages of the research cycle. It prioritizes reliability, ensuring quality of research at all stages of the research process, honesty, developing, conducting, sharing, and engaging with research in fair, transparent ways.
Respect for research participants, colleagues, society, culture, and the environment. And accountability for the research, its management, and for wider impacts.
Why is research integrity important? 1. It reduces the likelihood of research misconduct. 2. It ensures the validity of research results. 3. It facilitates trust between researchers. 4. It promotes trust in data and research expertise.
Pre-registration
A pre-registration is a record of research processes. It is created and shared before data are collected or become accessible. It is a timestamped record of decisions about study design, methods, and analysis. Pre-registration documents should be publicly available. There are dedicated repositories to make pre-registrations available.
Why is pre-registration important? 1. It encourages researchers to identify the goals of their project before collecting any data. 2. It creates accountability in research. 3. It discourages researchers from conducting after the-actalyses to find significant, novel, and or exciting results. 4. It makes research findings easier to find.
Open reporting
Research involves choices and revisions at each stage. Open reporting allows us to make our processes and our outputs transparent.
Open reporting involves providing a full, clear, and specific account of how research was conducted. It is supported by use of open reporting checklists.
Why is open reporting important?

It allows researchers to detail their processes and decisions at all stages of the research cycle.
It enhances other researchers ability to evaluate a study‚Äôs results.
It enhances other researchers abilities to reproduce a study‚Äôs results.
It benefits decision making at individual and societal levels because decisions can be made on transparent processes and findings.

Data management
Data is all information collected, observed, recorded or created throughout the research process. It can include spreadsheets, videos, audios, notes, diaries, images.
Data management. Research data management is the organization, storage and preservation of research data during active research and post project.
A data management plan or DMP is a living document which describes the organization, storage, preservation and potential sharing of research data and is an integral part of open research practice.
Why is data management important?

It helps you keep track of your own work.
It protects against data loss.
It increases research efficiency.
It minimizes errors in data mission.
There are funding and publishing incentives related to data management.
There are institutional and/or legal data management requirements.

Why is open data important?
Remember that open data is data made publicly available. 1. It enhances accountability. 2. It enhances transparency. 3. It enhances reproducibility. 4. It facilitates revisiting and building on existing data. 5. It facilitates better and stronger collaborations. 6. It is better value for the public money that funds much research.
Open knowledge dissemination
Open knowledge dissemination means communicating knowledge gained from research in open and accessible ways. This expands on the traditional approach to sharing research knowledge, which involves publishing it in an academic journal that can often only be accessed by paying a fee.
Approaches to open knowledge dissemination include open access publishing. Anyone can access the published research without paying a fee. Preprints, versions of research papers made available online before being peer-reviewed and published. Repositories, databases people can use to store and access research papers and/or data sets.
Science communication. sharing research in a way that increases appreciation, excitement, understanding and impact of research and data visualization representing data graphically or visually to increase its accessibility.
Why is open knowledge dissemination important?

It increases public access to and interest in research.
It increases the transparency and openness of research.
It helps reshape what is considered important in research and academia.

title: 2. Research Integrity
section: What practices can compromise research integrity?
text:
What practices can compromise research integrity?

Plagiarism, including self-plagiarism, giving or taking credit for work inappropriately.
Fabricating data, misrepresenting data, manipulation of images or other materials, undeclared conflicts of interest.

What is plagiarism?

Plagiarism is a practice of misrepresenting someone else‚Äôs words or ideas as your own. It is also possible to self-plagiarize.
This happens when an author passes off old work as new. For example, by submitting one paper for credit in two separate modules.
How do you avoid plagiarism?


Always acknowledge the work and contributions of other people.
When paraphrasing or summarizing someone else‚Äôs work, include a citation.
If including text from someone else‚Äôs work verbatim, use quotation marks and include a citation.
Cite primary sources of information rather than secondary or tertiary sources.


Your university will have resources to help you avoid plagiarism, too. In UCC, for example, a citing, referencing, and plagiarism course is available here.
And check out this video on how to cite sources. And this one on examples of plagiarism. They are short but very useful.
Giving or taking credit for work inappropriately

If someone makes a meaningful contribution to a research project, they should receive credit for their contribution. This might mean they are an author on a final paper or receive an acknowledgement on that paper.
There is guidance to determine if someone makes a meaningful contribution like the IC JME criteria.

You might also ask yourself, did they contribute to the study idea design? Did they conduct analyses or contribute to interpreting findings? Did they assist with writing up the final report paper?

If someone doesn‚Äôt make a meaningful contribution, they shouldn‚Äôt be given credit. For instance, listing uninvolved members of a research group or more senior academics who only looked at the final paper. These kind of authors are sometimes called ghost authors.


Data fabrication

Data fabrication is a process of manufacturing or making up data. For example, an anthropologist might write transcripts of interviews they never conducted. These transcripts, false data, might become part of the research record.
This can result in unreliable data and waste research resources through attempted replications.
Covid 19 example

A paper published in 2020 reported increased risk of debt for people hospitalized with Covid 19 if they had underlying cardiovascular disease.

Findings were based on data supposedly collected by the company of one of the study authors. It quickly became apparent that the data was fraudulent. The paper was retracted, but such questionable practices can undermine trust in research.


Data misrepresentation

Data misrepresentation is a practice of presenting real data in a misleading way. Researchers might emphasize exciting or novel findings only. Researchers might also distort or duplicate images of their findings.
Some researchers even magnified or reverse their images to try and avoid detection.

Data misrepresentation gives an incomplete picture of the research findings. Like other questionable research practices, it can result in unreliable data. It can also waste research resources through attempted replications.
Piracy and manipulation of images, other materials

Sometimes researchers manipulate figures, images, or other resources to include them in multiple research papers. Often these manipulated materials come from organizations known as paper mills.

Paper mills turn out fake data, images, and whole papers to meet demand from researchers. But there are also researchers working to identify this manipulated content so it can be retracted.


Undeclared conflicts of interest

A conflict of interest is when a researcher‚Äôs other interests lead to intentional or unintentional biases in research.
Conflicts of interest may in turn compromise the validity of the results.

For example, a researcher receiving funding for pharmaceutical development may be incentivized to demonstrate that competitors drugs are unsafe or inferior. This may shape how they conduct their research and impact the findings which will influence people‚Äôs health and care in the future.
Why do people engage in research misconduct?

There are several factors that can motivate research misconduct. Some are emotional like fear of failure. Misconduct may also be motivated by external pressures like pressure from supervisors to achieve a certain result.
Researchers may also feel pressure to perform due to the competitiveness of academic culture. Worries about personal circumstances like employment status might also motivate misconduct.

section: How can you maintain high levels of research integrity?
text:
How can you maintain high levels of research integrity?
How can I help reduce the effects of research misconduct?

Follow best practices in research integrity and open research at all stages of the research process.
Avoid plagiarism.
Accurately and honestly represent your data.
Give credit where it is due.
Be transparent and responsible in all aspects of and decisions about your research.

How can I help reduce the effects of research misconduct?
You can also comment on and review already published papers using platforms like Pubpeer. This helps flag issues in research that are already in the public domain.
Pubier is an online journal club that exists as an app on the Chrome browser. It allows researchers to comment on published journal articles. This is called postpublication peer review.
Researchers can highlight problems in analysis, interpretation, and/or reporting of results. Pubier has contributed to many corrections and retractions of published articles.
Most universities have a research code of conduct that outlines what to do if you suspect research misconduct in your university. Research misconduct can usually be reported in writing to an established research integrity officer in your institution. This is someone trained to follow up and investigate suspected misconduct.
If you suspect research misconduct outside of your university, you can contact the editors or administrators of the journal website where the work appears.
What happens then? Processes are in place in your university to manage the outcomes of research integrity issues. Your research support office can guide you on this.
When research integrity issues or misconduct are identified in published research, these studies are retracted.
The paper is withdrawn from the journal in which it is published. It may still be available online, but it include a notification that it has been retracted.
Retraction Watch, which was launched in 2010, is a blog that tracks retracted papers. The Retraction Watch database contains entries for each retracted paper. By the end of 2020, there were nearly 25,000 retracted papers in the database. Retraction Watch also keeps track of individual researchers with multiple retractions in its leaderboard.
You can check out Retraction Watch here.

Educate yourself about research integrity.
Follow institutional codes of conduct for research. University College Cork‚Äôs research code of conduct is available here.

How is this different to an ethics application? For many research projects, you will need to submit an ethics application. title: 3. Pre-registration
text:
Why is pre-registration important?


It encourages researchers to identify the goals of their project before collecting data or starting analysis.
It creates accountability in research.
It discourages researchers from conducting after the fact analyses to find significant, novel, or exciting results.
It helps researchers manage the personal biases that might influence their research.
It makes research findings easier to locate.

Why should you pre-register your study?

Pre-registration is easy once you‚Äôve learned how to do it. It builds your reputation as a researcher and allows you to take credit for your ideas and plans. You may also be able to earn a digital badge for pre-registering your study. These are offered by over 60 research journals in multiple disciplines.
Why aren‚Äôt all studies pre-registered?

Pre-registration might present challenges for some types of research like exploratory research or secondary analysis. But challenges do not mean it can‚Äôt be done.

Pre-registration takes time, planning, and figuring out requirements for pre-registration for the target repository.
Some researchers think pre-registration is not applicable or appropriate for more constructivist research. But being transparent about what we plan to do before we begin our research projects is important for any type of research.

title: 3. Pre-registration
section: How do you pre-register a study?
text:
How do you pre-register a study?

Pre-registering your study. It sounds like a lot of work. And what if I want to change my research plan?

Your pre-registration is the research plan you will put together with your supervisor and or for ethics approval. So you will be doing much of the work anyway. There are lots of resources and templates you can use to pre-register. This makes it much easier.

You can also update your pre-registration up until you begin data analysis. Your pre-registration will outline how you plan to conduct your study and can be amended up to a point.

Okay, sounds good. So, how do I actually do it?

To pre-register your study, you need to decide the following in advance: your study design and methods, how you will collect your data, and how you will analyze your data.


You should have a clear plan including all the relevant information and details.
You then need to decide where you are going to pre-register your study.
Different pre-registration platforms will provide templates for pre-registering your study.
Templates are meant to serve as a guide because pre-registration may require some flexibility.


Different disciplines may require different methods for pre-registration. A list of discipline specific templates is included in the Additional Resources section. This is not an exhaustive list and there may be other applicable templates.

Pre-registering on OSF

OSF Open Science Framework is a popular repository or platform for pre-registering projects. For this reason, paper trail focuses on OSF for pre-registration.
Pre-registering on OSF

A complete guide to pre-registering projects on OSF is available on their website here. A brief overview is presented on the next slide.
Remember, another platform may be more suitable for you, but for this course, we are just focusing on OSF.
Here are the steps to pre-register on OSF


Set up an account on the Open Science Framework.
Select to start a new pre-registration.
Include your project title and a description. This is called your metadata.
Include your research plan. This is your research design or approach and how you will collect and analyze data.
Register it and make it public. You can make it immediately public or public at a later date.
Preview and review your pre-registration.
You can add attachments if you need more space or have additional components to share.

title: 3. Pre-registration
text:
What is a registered report?

Typically, when we want to publish a paper, we submit it to a journal after the study is finished. The journal and its peer reviewers then decide if the study can be published in that journal.
There is evidence that studies with significant novel or exciting findings are more likely to get published.

What are registered reports?


Registered reports are research papers outlining the proposed study methods and approach.
The potential for publication of these papers is evaluated by the journal before any data collection.
This means they are evaluating the proposed study methods rather than the findings.



What is a Registered Report?

Stage 1.
Researchers submit their research question, questions, theory, hypothesis, detailed methods, analysis plans, and any existing data. Studies are then reviewed. If the review is favorable, the study receives an inprincipal acceptance and is registered in a repository. The research is then conducted.
Stage 2.
Researchers then submit completed manuscripts including:

Open data is data that that has made publicly available without any restrictions. It is data that is available to anyone to access, use and share the fair principles and data management plans enable open data sharing. Making data openly available reinforces the principles of open research.
Why is open data important?

section: How can I make my data open?
text:
How can I make my data open?

How can I make my data open? A good place to start is a FAIR data principles. The FAIR principles outlined the importance of making data findable, accessible, interoperable, and reuseable.
The FAIR principles

The FAIR principles provide a framework for research data management. This enables and supports sharing of research data. They also facilitate control over access to deserts that need to be protected where required data can be as open as possible, but also as close as necessary.

With FAIR, you can make your data findable, accessible and reusable by yourself, or make it interoperable will require additional supports.
Why are FAIR principles important?


Sharing data, according to Fair Principles, helps ensure that others have enough information to verify or reuse your data.
To help to make your data more transparent.
They have to make your data more reusable,
They help to make your research more reproducible (see the next module on Reproducible Research Practices).

Why isn‚Äôt all research data open?

Not all data can be made publicly available due to ethical privacy, safety or legal considerations.

Data may be sensitive in nature, i.e.¬†the location of endangered species, or it may be impossible to completely anonymize.
It may also not be appropriate for reuse data.
Data might also not be made open because the researcher did not get informed consent to use participant data in this way.


With this in mind, the FAIR principles allow for close data and include the caveat that data should be as open as possible, but as close as necessary.
What about qualitative data?

Qualitative data from interviews, for instance, can be of an intimate nature and sensitive information may be disclosed. In addition, the public are not always clear about or comfortable with qualitative data sharing.
So it is important to clearly outline data sharing procedures when gaining informed consent.

It is also important to practise data minimisation, this means not collecting more information than is strictly needed. And it is important to replace information that could be used to identify individuals with a pseudonym.

title: 4. Research & Data Management
text:
Data Management
What is data management?

Data management is a series of processes employed throughout the research cycle to manage data, data lifecycle, plan, create, process, analyse, preserve, share, reuse.
Why is data management important?


It helps you keep track of your own work and protect against data loss.
It increases research efficiency.
It minimises errors and data omission.
There are funding and publishing incentives for good data management.
There are institutional and legal requirements for good data management.
Data management enables and facilitates sharing of research data as FAIR and open data.

What is a data management plan?

It is the living document, which is developed at the outset of a research project and updated throughout. It details how data will be organised, managed, stored, what the project is active and how it will be preserved and shared if relevant. Once the study is over, it is a core good research practice and ensures research.
Reproducibility is important to familiarise yourself with data management plans early in your research journey.
Why are data management plans important?


They set out transparent data practises for the research project.
They make it easy to find and understand your data when you need to use it.
They help to avoid unnecessary duplication, e.g.¬†collecting data.
They help you maintain your data so that it can be validated by other researchers.
They help you remember what you did and what you plan to do with your data.
Well managed research data can also be another output from a project which is good for your CV.

Things to consider when making a data management plan


What are the ethical requirements for your data?
How will you collect your data?
What metadata and or other documentation can go with your data?
How will you backup your data?
Can will you share your data? And if so, how?


Think about the data before collecting any. The first question you should think about is what type of data will I be collecting during my project? Think in terms of the type, volume and frequency of data.
What is metadata?

Metadata is data about your data. It can be contextual information provided with your data, i.e.¬†variable names, types of measurement. It can include things like keywords to help people find your data. These give your data meaning and make them findable and reusable.
How do you create a data management plan?

Use these six headings to begin drafting a data management plan.

Data collection
Documentation and metadata.
Storage and backup during active research
Legal and ethical considerations.
Data sharing and long term preservation, FAIR and open data.
Data Management Responsibilities.

Take a look at the data management template to get a sense of what is required.
Where can I share my data?

Research data can be shared openly in many repositories worldwide. There are lots of examples of repositories where you can make your data openly available. Some are generally, e.g., Zenodo, Figshare, Software Heritage.

For specialist data repositories, FAIRsharing.org is a good place to start.
Here you can search data repositories according to kind of data you are working with.
Steps towards open data

An essential first step is to discuss what is possible and appropriate for your data with your supervisor, then develop and implement a data management plan which include provision and plans for making data fair and open.

Review your data and metadata for completeness and quality, then choose your data repository and upload your data!

title: 5. Reproducible practices
text:
What is reproducibility?
‚è≠Ô∏è Skip ahead to watch the video presentation
üìä or see the slides
What is research reproducibility?
If another researcher cannot reproduce the research, this does not necessarily mean the findings aren‚Äôt valid. This is because reproducibility does not equal truth. But lack of reproducibility does raise questions about a study‚Äôs validity and reliability.
Reproducibility can also be understood as:
Reproducible research involves sharing data and research procedures, making these available for public peer evaluation, taking steps in the study design process to minimize bias.
Reproducibility across disciplines
The concept of reproducibility was developed in science and is primarily oriented around quantitative data. It has traditionally focused on how we can go from a dataset, visualize the information, and demonstrate the analyses that are applied, all of which can be achieved using reproducible scripted workflows.
So reproducibility may reflect scientific assumptions that do not translate easily to other disciplines.
So what about qualitative research, and our research conducted in the social sciences, arts, and the humanities? Exact data replication may not be possible or even advantageous in some cases. Ethical commitments may prevent the sharing of complete datasets.
The amount and kinds of data that can be disclosed in qualitative and social research may depend on a variety of factors: the relationship between researcher and participant, sample characteristics, the research setting, the information being documented, for example, interview data.
There are still approaches that can be taken in non-science disciplines. This type of research should prioritize transparency by providing details about how the research was conducted.
‚ÄúCrisis‚Äù versus ‚ÄúRenaissance‚Äù
There is an argument that what is currently being described as a reproducibility crisis is actually a renaissance in that the focus on reproducibility has highlighted existing problems and proposes ways to address them.
This is resulting in new ways of thinking about and conducting research, and is leading to improvements in research.

title: 5. Reproducible practices
text:
Reproducibility examples

To err is to be human.
Often, the mistakes made inadvertently lie hidden, never to be found. Through the incorporation of reproducible practices within our work, we can identify and correct these mistakes after the event, improving the quality of our reporting. Check out the next four slides for examples.

Example 1. Identifying reproducibility issues in a clinical trial.
Clinical trials are studies that examine, typically, treatments on human health outcomes. In 2018, a major medical journal retracted an important clinical trial after a serious error was detected in how the trial data was processed.

In this trial, the treatment and control groups had their coding reversed. This means that what the researchers thought was data from the treatment group was actually data from the control group and vice versa.

This was an inadvertent mistake that invalidated the trial results. The mistake was only found because the code underlying the results was published and so could be examined. Someone who examined the code spotted the mistake. In this way, reproducible research practices saved the day.

Example 2. Power Posing
In 2010, researchers published results from a psychological study suggesting that power posing, or standing or adopting an assertive posture, can improve confidence. These findings were disseminated widely, and the concept of power posing quickly found its way into popular culture.

Two years later, however, the results of the study were called into question when a replication study failed to find the same results. This was particularly the case for changes that the original researchers had reported for certain hormones as a result of power posing.
In addition, increased scrutiny of the original research revealed that the statistical significance values associated with the work were barely significant.

The research was, for a time, dismissed as pseudoscience. However, preregistered and robust replication studies have supported that power posing is linked to people‚Äôs feelings of confidence now. This reaffirms a link between posture and confidence. It also demonstrates the importance of being able to reproduce studies to determine potentially erroneous and/or valid findings.

title: 5. Reproducible practices
text:
Why is reproducibility important?


It ensures research can be assessed, verified, and confirmed by other researchers.
It helps identify and correct situations where researchers have engaged in questionable research practices.
Creating a culture of reproducibility can discourage researchers from reporting only those findings that are significant or exciting.

How does this impact you?

Engaging in reproducible practices minimizes the likelihood of questionable research practices, no matter what discipline you are in. It can make research better by reducing bias and/or teasing out other flaws in research. The assessors or markers of your final research project can see how thorough and transparent you have been. While reproducibility practices may take a bit more of your time, they pay off in the end!

If you want to publish your research, journals are now publishing more reproduction studies and negative results.
Being able to assess published research for reproducibility gives you a better understanding of what research is reliable (or not).

It also helps develop a more reliable evidence base for policy or practice decisions that impact society.

title: 5. Reproducible practices
section: How do we make research more reproducible?
text:
How do we make research more reproducible?
What kinds of things decrease reproducibility?

There are lots of things that can impact on reproducibility, things like flaws in study design, researcher biases, and misunderstanding analytical approaches.

Reproducibility may also be decreased by poor record keeping, mistakes, and lack of training, as well as poor sharing of research approaches, selective reporting of findings and methods, and incentives to publish more and faster at the cost of rigor.
How can we make research more reliable and reproducible?


Carefully document your methods using a data management plan.
Use a uniform filing system with clear folder and filing names.
Store metadata alongside the primary data. Metadata is data about data.
Store all research materials in accordance with institutional guidelines.
Consider keeping a digital notebook to share processes and steps used to generate findings.

How can we make research more reliable and reproducible?

If you are working with data that can be more readily made available, make your data and details of methods freely available to other researchers by publishing the data in a repository such as OSF, which you were introduced to in module two. Always including a data dictionary to accompany your data. A data dictionary gives clear information about your data. Using open-sourced software and providing information about statistical tests or other analytical approaches employed and the arguments used.

In some disciplines, it‚Äôs not as easy or possible to make data available. If it is not possible, remember the importance of enhancing transparency by providing details about how the research was conducted. These details can include the theoretical method adopted, the research setting, the relationship between researcher and participants, anonymized patient characteristics.

Strategies to make your research more reproducible are presented throughout the PaportTrail course: Research Integrity, Research Data Management, Open Reporting, Knowledge Dissemination.

There are resources available to help. Examples of resources in University College Cork include a digital badge in the responsible conduct of research that includes training on research reproducibility.
There are post-graduate modules on reproducible research Practices, PG6030, and an Introduction to Research Integrity, Ethics, and Open Science, PG6015.
The UCC Boole Library also run a variety of training sessions. Other universities may have supports including training and workshops to support you to develop reproducible research methods.

There are also online networks and communities you can follow and join. For example, the UK Reproducibility Network, UKRN.

The UKRN provides guidance and resources for methods and strategies for improving research reproducibility.
Reproducibility for Everyone, this provides resources and webinars on strategies for reproducible research.
ReproducibiliTea, a community for early-stage researchers interested in open science and reproducibility.

What efforts are universities and supervisors making to help us make research more reproducible?

Efforts are increasing by supervisors and universities to support students.

One example of this, being led by Dr.¬†Katherine Button, the University of Bath, is a collaborative approach to open research projects. In this model, students in a number of UK universities participate in a consortium to complete their final-year theses. The students receive extra support throughout the project to make their research reproducible.

text:
What is Open Reporting?
‚è≠Ô∏è Skip ahead to watch the video presentation
üìä or see the slides
Open reporting is the practice of providing a full, clear, and specific account of how research was conducted. This is done according to a standard template or set of guidelines.
Open reporting applies to all stages of the research process, from planning, to data collection, analysis, and write-up, to dissemination.
It can be easy to focus only on reporting the findings of our research, but research involves choices and revisions at every stage of the process. Open reporting allows us to make our processes transparent, as well as our findings.
Is open reporting applicable to all disciplines, though? Yes, but it is not currently in use in all disciplines. All disciplines are on their own open research journey, developing and adapting their own version.
Most existing checklists and guidelines relate to medicine and health, and related disciplines.
It won‚Äôt be the same for everyone, and currently there are lots of gaps. But it is still important to know what it is and how to do it so you are prepared to report openly, and can better understand and evaluate how others report their research.

title: 6. Open reporting
text:
Why is Open Reporting Important?

Traditionally, research reports place an emphasis on results, which has meant that other parts of the research process remain opaque. This limits other researchers‚Äô abilities to evaluate or attempt to reproduce a study‚Äôs results. If flaws go undetected, invalid research results may still become part of the research record.
This may increase research waste as other researchers attempt to reproduce or build upon flawed evidence. It may also unduly impact both individual decisions and social policy.


It allows researchers to detail their processes and decisions at all stages of the research cycle.
It enhances other researchers‚Äô ability to evaluate and/or verify a study‚Äôs results.
It enhances other researchers‚Äô ability to reproduce a study‚Äôs results.
It facilitates researchers‚Äô ability to bring together large bodies of evidence to better understand topics.
It benefits decision-making because decisions can be made on transparent research processes and findings.

Why is open reporting important for me?

That all sounds great for research more generally, but what about me as a student? It sounds like it takes extra time, and I‚Äôm not sure how I will benefit. By openly reporting what you have done in your research, you have a transparent account of your study.

This makes it easier for others, including your research supervisor, to see the steps you have taken. This can help to spot mistakes earlier on and correct them, and can help you get recognition for the work you put in at each step.
There are also lots of tools and resources to help you openly report. We will go through these in the next section.

title: 6. Open reporting
section: How can we report research openly?
text:
How can we report research openly?

In this section, we focus on reporting guidelines and checklists.

How can we report research results openly? You can also openly report using pre-registration. This means making your research plans and processes publicly available before you start. Registered reports, these are research papers outlining proposed study methods and approach that are submitted to journals beforehand. You can find out more about pre-registration and registered reports in the module on Pre-registration.
What is a reporting guideline?

It is the checklist, a structured text, or a flow diagram that guides researchers in how to report a specific type of research that has been developed using explicit methodology.

What is the aim of a reporting guideline?

To help researchers create accessible and easily understood records of their research.
To help researchers create relevant records of their research.
To help researchers create records of their work containing sufficient detail to allow evaluation and/or reproduction.

Reporting guidelines and checklists

When should I use an open reporting checklist? They are typically used when writing research reports and articles. Many journals now require you to submit a completed checklist with your submitted paper.
You can also use the checklists to guide your thinking and drafting of your protocol and/or ethics application.

Reporting guidelines and checklists are also useful to guide your process as well as essential to complete when writing up your final report. So how do I find a reporting guideline for my research, and how do I know which one is the right one to use?
There are resources you can use like the EQUATOR Network website. This has a list of guidelines you can use, and many are available in many different languages.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
What is the traditional approach to knowledge dissemination?
‚è≠Ô∏è Skip ahead to watch the video presentation üìä or see the slides
What is open knowledge dissemination?
Dissemination is the term used to describe how research is shared. It includes the processes researchers use to share research with other researchers and the general public.
To understand what open dissemination is, it is helpful to first think about how dissemination of research has typically been conducted. Traditional dissemination consisted of the steps outlined in the next slide.
How is research typically disseminated?
Step 1. Designing and conducting research.
Step 2. Analysing data and generating results.
Step 3. Writing up the research findings in the form of a journal article and submitting this for publication in an academic journal.
Step 4. The study undergoes peer review, and a decision is made about whether the article can be accepted, needs to be revised or is rejected.
Step 5. Eventually the article will be published on the Journal website and or in print.
What are some of the challenges of traditional knowledge dissemination?
So paywalls and barriers to accessing knowledge also impact on transparency of research. And if research is not disseminated transparently, it can‚Äôt be learnt from and or built upon.
Another problem is that the traditional processes may be biased towards publishing novel, exciting and or significant results. This is a phenomenon known as the file drawer problem. It means that only some findings are available which can bias our understanding and means we only have an incomplete picture.
What are some of the challenges of traditional knowledge dissemination?
It is also a big problem because it can influence which questions researchers choose to ask. So research becomes focussed on what researchers can get published rather than on what we should be examining.
It can also incentivise researchers to engage in questionable research or reporting practises to produce novel, exciting and or significant results.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
What is open knowledge dissemination?


It involves sharing research more quickly and openly than in a traditional approach.
It includes approaches that can reduce inequalities by sharing information and broader, more accessible ways.
It is not only open access publishing, although this is an important component.

Methods for openly disseminating research

1. Open access publishing
2. Preprint
3. Online repositories
4. Science communication
5. Citizen science
We will take you through these and the following module sections.
Potential obstacles to open research dissemination

Making research papers openly available involves fees that researchers must pay. This is not always possible.
Some forms of open knowledge dissemination do not require research to be peer reviewed and checked. This may lead to dissemination of lower quality research, however, the challenges of monitoring quality of openly disseminated research may be balanced by increased transparency and post publication peer review. It is also increasingly clear that traditional approaches to dissemination do not also ensure quality either.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
section: Why is open knowledge dissemination important?
text:
Why is open knowledge dissemination important?
Methods for openly disseminating research

Open dissemination methods facilitate:
1. Transparency in research to better access
2. Knowledge for individuals and society
3. Equity in access to knowledge
4. Reshaping of how researchers are rewarded or incentivised to do research
5. Rewarding methodological rigour and integrity instead of just findings
6. Quicker availability of research findings compared to traditional routes
7. Making research more easily accessible with less or no cost.

Open dissemination methods can increase your visibility as a researcher, and the visibility of your research. They make it easier for you to access the research and information you need, and give you more control over what, when and how you share your research.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
Open Access Publishing
What is open access publishing?

Open access publishing means publishing research in a format so that it is made openly available for anyone to read without any cost to the reader. There are many dedicated open access journals where people can publish their research openly. There are also increasing numbers of journals offering an open access publishing option in addition to the standard publishing approach. Research funders are increasingly requiring funded researchers to publish their findings open access.

Open access publishing has costs for the researcher, though, who usually has to pay fees to make their research openly available.
This is a barrier to open publishing. It also reflects a bigger problem of costs in publishing, either way, that public money funds research, but there are always costs involved for the public to be able to access.

There are other approaches like preprint that can help get around these issues. We‚Äôll discuss these soon.
Benefits of open access


It is easier for everyone, including you, to access research if it is published as open access.
Open access publishing allows citizens to share in knowledge and evidence on issues that affects them.



Open access publications can increase exposure and impact of your research.
Open access publications are reported to receive more media coverage.



A lot of research is funded by public money awarded through grants, so open access makes sure the public can see what they have funded.

How do I make my research open access?

If you go on to publish your research project, you can consider publishing it in an open access publication. The directory of open access journals provides a list of such journals across multiple disciplines.

Remember, though, that open access publications have costs for you as the researcher submitting the paper. You can often apply for open access fee waivers, especially for student work that is not supported by funding. Waivers are not always granted, though, so open access publishing may not always be possible due to cost.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
Preprints
What are preprints?

Preprints are copies of research manuscripts that have been uploaded to designated preprint servers before undergoing journal peer review. They are the same manuscript that will be submitted to a journal, so they represent the final work.
Are men who smoke at higher risk for more severe case of Covid-19 than women who smoke? A systematic review.
This is an example of a preprint published by students and their supervisor from UCC.
Benefits and drawbacks to preprint

Uploading a pre-print of your manuscript allows for free and rapid dissemination of your research. When reading reprints, it is important to remember that they have not been peer reviewed and so should be read with a degree of caution.

While many journals now have policies allowing and encouraging preconceive research articles, some do not accept preprint. There are ways to check which journals do and don‚Äôt accept preference. We talk more about this shortly.
How do I do a preprint?

If you are planning to publish your research project, you can upload a copy of the final manuscript to a pre-print server. You must do this before you submit it to a journal for peer review.

OK, but how do I actually prepare my manuscript and find where to upload it? An important first step is talking to your supervisor about making your research available as a pre-print.

You should then identify a suitable preprint server. Some examples are archived bioRxiv, medRxiv and arXiv. You can see examples of preference on any of the above servers to help guide you in preparing to upload your preprint.
As your preprint is the same manuscript that you will submit to the journal. Any changes to your manuscript will mostly be formatting and uploading requirements.

It is very important to check that the journal you want to publish your manuscript in accepts prints, share Borromeo provides up to date information about individual journals, open access policies. So check here first.

Once you are sure your target journal accept preprints, you have identified a relevant preprint server and have prepared your paper, you can upload it to the pre-print server.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
Repositories
What are repositories?

A repository is a database for storing data sets or research outputs, e.g.¬†manuscript‚Äôs. Many universities have their own repositories for affiliated researchers to use e.g., Coursera and UCC.
Putting research outputs on repositories can make them more visible. Researchers have control over what is made publicly available when putting data or outputs on repositories.


Repositories can be domain or discipline specific or maybe more general.
Examples of domain specific repositories, Leanness, Health Research, Emelle, a core humanities Izidor, social sciences and humanities.
Examples of more general repositories, open science framework and Xanadu.


To upload your research paper, manuscript or data, you must first identify an appropriate repository. Once you have identified a repository, follow the repository guidance to upload your paper or data.
An important note on uploading data to a repository

If you were uploading data to an online repository, make sure you are adhering to ethical considerations and data sharing guidelines.
You should complete the PaporTrail module on Research and Data Management to find out more about this. You should also consult your institutional research and data sharing guidelines and support services.

The OSFI allows researchers to:
1) Store and make available their research outputs
2) manage their workflows and keep projects organised
3) store data analyses and reports
4) assign a digital object identifier to their project
5) link projects to researcher.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
Science Communication
What is science communication?


Sharing research ideas, methods and knowledge with non expert audiences.
Sharing these in ways which are useful, understandable, accessible and or tailored.
The goal is to inform the public.
This is usually done in engaging ways to also increase interest in research and its outputs and to influence people‚Äôs opinions and behaviours.


Communicating the findings of your research is as important as conducting the research.
Science communication is not limited to traditional academic approaches, but can incorporate a range of different approaches.

Science communication is not just for science. It can incorporate a range of different approaches aimed at the target audience, including the wider community or special interest groups, e.g.¬†policymaker‚Äôs blogs, public talks and images.

Approaches can include things like public talks, e.g., point of science, social media, including using GIFs, check, hashtag, a bit of cake for good examples of student research.
Blog posts like this one about personalised medicine, videos using visuals or infographics, podcasts like the Orion Open Science Podcast and newspapers and the media.

Benefits of Science Communication


It enhances the sharing of research findings.
It increases public understanding of research.
It increases public interest in research and for it can help research to make an impact by reaching target audiences.

How do I do science communication if you aren‚Äôt ready to share your research with the public?

Yes, a good starting place with science communication is to see how other people are doing is.

There are likely blogs relevant to your discipline or research interests that you could look at.



Graphical abstracts, which visually represent the research, are becoming increasingly common in journal publications.
There are thousands of TED and TED talks, which you can watch Twitter threads, YouTube and other social media include examples of science communication too.



There are also local, national and international activities you can attend. Your university may have events and competitions like a three minute thesis where researchers present their research in three minutes.



Other activities include things like point of science, where researchers present their research in a pub setting Fame Lab, which is an international science communication competition for researchers, including research students.


When you‚Äôre ready to share your research, you might want to take part in some of these activities.
When you are ready to share your research with the public, it is important to first identify who your target audience is. Is it everyone or is it a specific group that your research is most relevant to?

Think about what message or messages you want to share, what are the key findings, the things that are most important for your audience to know?
Think about ways that you can share this information.
There are lots of options like in-person talks or using videos, visual representations, podcasts or blog posts.

It is important that you avoid using technical terms or jargon when sharing your research with the public, you want it to be accessible to everyone.
Try to include visuals as well as speaking text, this can maintain attention and keep it interesting for the audience.
How do I do science communication?

Make it relatable. Remember, you are not communicating as a researcher to other researchers, so only include examples and anecdotes that are relatable to your target audience.

Remember that because science communication aims for exclusivity, it can be difficult for the audience to decide what is reliable information.
If you were doing science communication, be sure to support your points with accessible data and or supporting information.
If you are viewing science communication, put your researcher hat on to determine if the communicator is supporting their points.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
Citizen Science
What is citizen science?


It is an open and inclusive approach to conducting research.
It involves input from the public in the research process as observers identifying images or providing or analysing data.
It is an aim of open research because open research works towards exclusivity,
It is also an enabler of open research because including the public and research increases its openness.
It is not simply having members of the public involved as participants. They are instead active research partners.

Benefits of citizen science

It promotes research that is conducted for the people and by the people. It enhances public engagement in and with research. It nurtures public investment in an understanding of scientific processes and outputs.
Case study: The people‚Äôs trial

Check out the people‚Äôs trial for an excellent example of citizen science and science, communication and action. The public were involved in all stages of the project from deciding what research question to examine, to deciding how the findings should be shared.

For example, the public were asked to come up with possible research questions, they came up with 155 questions.

The public then voted on which one they should examine, the question they decided on was: Does reading a book in bed make a difference to sleep in comparison to not reading a book in bed?

This video was used to explain the what, why and how of deciding a research question.
Find out more about the people‚Äôs trial by visiting their website.

Citizen science is a bit trickier to include in a student project. You can get involved in ongoing citizen science projects that you come across. For instance, projects like the All Ireland Ladybird survey that involves the public in tracking Ireland‚Äôs native Ledebur population using a smartphone app.

title: 7. Knowledge dissemination
text:
Video







Video transcript - Open Knowledge Dissemination





What is the traditional approach to knowledge dissemination?
What is open knowledge dissemination? Dissemination is the term used to describe how research is shared. It includes the processes researchers use to share research with other researchers and the general public.
To understand what open dissemination is, it is helpful to first think about how dissemination of research has typically been conducted. Traditional dissemination consisted of the steps outlined in the next slide.
How is research typically disseminated? Step 1. Designing and conducting research. Step 2. Analysing data and generating results. Step 3. Writing up the research findings in the form of a journal article and submitting this for publication in an academic journal. Step 4. The study undergoes peer review, and a decision is made about whether the article can be accepted, needs to be revised or is rejected. Step 5. Eventually the article will be published on the Journal website and or in print.
What are some of the challenges of traditional knowledge dissemination? - It can take a long time for researchers to get their findings published and for anyone interested to be able to read them. - Articles in traditional journals are often behind paywalls, which means they can only be accessed by paying a subscription or fee. This makes it harder for people to access the information, you‚Äôve probably already encountered this as a student. - In addition, institutions may subscribe to journals, but not all institutions can afford the same fees. This can create and reinforce inequalities in access to knowledge.
So paywalls and barriers to accessing knowledge also impact on transparency of research. And if research is not disseminated transparently, it can‚Äôt be learnt from and or built upon.
Another problem is that the traditional processes may be biased towards publishing novel, exciting and or significant results. This is a phenomenon known as the file drawer problem. It means that only some findings are available which can bias our understanding and means we only have an incomplete picture.
What are some of the challenges of traditional knowledge dissemination? It is also a big problem because it can influence which questions researchers choose to ask. So research becomes focussed on what researchers can get published rather than on what we should be examining.
It can also incentivise researchers to engage in questionable research or reporting practises to produce novel, exciting and or significant results.
What is open knowledge dissemination?

It involves sharing research more quickly and openly than in a traditional approach.
It includes approaches that can reduce inequalities by sharing information and broader, more accessible ways.
It is not only open access publishing, although this is an important component.

Methods for openly disseminating research 1. Open access publishing 2. Preprint 3. Online repositories 4. Science communication 5. Citizen science
We will take you through these and the following module sections.
Potential obstacles to open research dissemination
Making research papers openly available involves fees that researchers must pay. This is not always possible.
Some forms of open knowledge dissemination do not require research to be peer reviewed and checked. This may lead to dissemination of lower quality research, however, the challenges of monitoring quality of openly disseminated research may be balanced by increased transparency and post publication peer review. It is also increasingly clear that traditional approaches to dissemination do not also ensure quality either.

What is pre-registration?
Pre-registration is timestamped. A timestamped record of research processes and decisions. It‚Äôs created in advance, created and shared before data are collected or become accessible and made publicly available. The pre-registration document should be publicly available on a registry or repository.
How is this different to an ethics application? For many research projects, you will need to submit an ethics application. This is typical for studies involving people, existing data, and in the sciences.
How is a pre-registration different to an ethics application? Pre-registrations and ethics applications contain much of the same information, but they serve different aims.
Why is pre-registration important?

It encourages researchers to identify the goals of their project before collecting data or starting analysis.
It creates accountability in research.
It discourages researchers from conducting after the fact analyses to find significant, novel, or exciting results.
It helps researchers manage the personal biases that might influence their research.
It makes research findings easier to locate.

Why should you pre-register your study?
Pre-registration is easy once you‚Äôve learned how to do it. It builds your reputation as a researcher and allows you to take credit for your ideas and plans. You may also be able to earn a digital badge for pre-registering your study. These are offered by over 60 research journals in multiple disciplines.
Why aren‚Äôt all studies pre-registered?
Pre-registration might present challenges for some types of research like exploratory research or secondary analysis. But challenges do not mean it can‚Äôt be done.
Why aren‚Äôt all studies pre-registered? Pre-registration takes time, planning, and figuring out requirements for pre-registration for the target repository.
Some researchers think pre-registration is not applicable or appropriate for more constructivist research. But being transparent about what we plan to do before we begin our research projects is important for any type of research.
How do you pre-register a study?
Pre-registering your study. It sounds like a lot of work. And what if I want to change my research plan?
Pre-registering your study. Your pre-registration is the research plan you will put together with your supervisor and or for ethics approval. So you will be doing much of the work anyway. There are lots of resources and templates you can use to pre-register. This makes it much easier.
Pre-registering your study. You can also update your pre-registration up until you begin data analysis. Your pre-registration will outline how you plan to conduct your study and can be amended up to a point.
Okay, sounds good. So, how do I actually do it?
How do you pre-register a study?
To pre-register your study, you need to decide the following in advance. Your study design and methods, how you will collect your data, and how you will analyze your data.
How do you pre-register a study?

You should have a clear plan including all the relevant information and details.
You then need to decide where you are going to pre-register your study.
Different pre-registration platforms will provide templates for pre-registering your study.
Templates are meant to serve as a guide because pre-registration may require some flexibility.

How do you pre-register a study?
Different disciplines may require different methods for pre-registration. A list of discipline specific templates is included in the additional resources section. This is not an exhaustive list and there may be other applicable templates.
Pre-registering on OSF.
OSF Open Science Framework is a popular repository or platform for pre-registering projects. For this reason, paper trail focuses on OSF for pre-registration.
Pre-registering on OSF. A complete guide to pre-registering projects on OSF is available on their website here. A brief overview is presented on the next slide.
Remember, another platform may be more suitable for you, but for this course, we are just focusing on OSF.
Pre-registering on OSF.

Set up an account on the Open Science Framework.
Select to start a new pre-registration.
Include your project title and a description. This is called your metadata.
Include your research plan. This is your research design or approach and how you will collect and analyze data.
Register it and make it public. You can make it immediately public or public at a later date.
Preview and review your pre-registration.
You can add attachments if you need more space or have additional components to share.

Pre-registering on OSF, the finished project.
On screen is an OSF pre-registration study protocol of the study factors that impact on the practice of open science by early career health researchers, a mixed method study. The full pre-registration of this study is included in the resources for your reference.
What is a registered report?
Typically, when we want to publish a paper, we submit it to a journal after the study is finished. The journal and its peer reviewers then decide if the study can be published in that journal.
There is evidence that studies with significant novel or exciting findings are more likely to get published.
What are registered reports?

Registered reports are research papers outlining the proposed study methods and approach.
The potential for publication of these papers is evaluated by the journal before any data collection.
This means they are evaluating the proposed study methods rather than the findings.

What is a Registered Report?
Stage I
Researchers submit their research question, questions, theory, hypothesis, detailed methods, analysis plans, and any existing data. Studies are then reviewed. If the review is favorable, the study receives an inprincipal acceptance and is registered in a repository. The research is then conducted.
In Stage II, researchers then submit completed manuscripts including:

A justification for the work, and
The approved protocol from stage one and
Results, discussion and any exploratory analysis.

How do you publish a registered report?
Plan your study. Submit study proposal to a journal. The proposal will be reviewed. Receive and respond to any feedbackand then if accepted do the study and publish the final paper in the journal.
Why are registered reports important?

They put the focus on the research question and the methodological quality of the study.
They alleviate perceived pressures to obtain significant or exciting results and to publish.
Many journals are starting to adopt registered reports as standard practice.
